--------------060905080901000608010402
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Hi all,

I wanted to inform the community that a new version of MultiNEAT is 
available and you can download it from the Github repo: 
https://github.com/peter-ch/MultiNEAT

The most important highlights about this release are:

- ES-HyperNEAT implementation with XOR example (contributed by Vik 
Chudinov ( vvch@... ), many thanks, Vik! )
- Python 3 support (it's kind of mandatory actually to run the examples, 
but you can still use 2.7)
- Better visualization (now it also displays the node type and 
activation), and new Matplotlib-based visualization (but slow).
- HyperNEAT doesn't use the link_threshold of 0.2 to create links 
anymore, but a separate output treated as signed step.
- HyperNEAT substrates accept custom connectivity patterns. Instead of 
querying the CPPN for all possible pairs of nodes, you can specify which 
ones. The substrate can still respect the general connectivity flags 
(like allow_hidden_hidden_links) if you want.
- The distance CPPN input for HyperNEAT now works for substrates of any 
dimensionality.
- New activation functions: Relu and Softplus rectifiers.

If you have trouble getting Boost to work with Python 3, compile it like 
this:

./bootstrap.sh --with-python=python3.4
./b2 -j8
sudo ./b2 install

OpenCV 3.0 now has Python 3 support so getting it to work shouldn't be a 
problem, though the installation may fail to copy the .so file in place. 
If that happens, locate the file manually in 
[your_build_dir]/lib/python3 and copy it in 
/usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages .

The documentation is not updated yet, but I'll do it in the next few 
weeks when I have time. The example files should be self-explanatory. Of 
course, always feel free to ask me anything.

Have fun!

Peter

--------------060905080901000608010402
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

  <body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" text="#000000">
    Hi all, <br>
    <br>
    I wanted to inform the community that a new version of MultiNEAT is
    available and you can download it from the Github repo:
    <a class="moz-txt-link-freetext" href="https://github.com/peter-ch/MultiNEAT">https://github.com/peter-ch/MultiNEAT</a> <br>
    <br>
    The most important highlights about this release are:<br>
    <br>
    - ES-HyperNEAT implementation with XOR example (contributed by Vik
    Chudinov ( <a class="moz-txt-link-abbreviated" href="mailto:vvch@...">vvch@...</a> ), many thanks, Vik! )<br>
    - Python 3 support (it's kind of mandatory actually to run the
    examples, but you can still use 2.7)<br>
    - Better visualization (now it also displays the node type and
    activation), and new Matplotlib-based visualization (but slow). <br>
    - HyperNEAT doesn't use the link_threshold of 0.2 to create links
    anymore, but a separate output treated as signed step. <br>
    - HyperNEAT substrates accept custom connectivity patterns. Instead
    of querying the CPPN for all possible pairs of nodes, you can
    specify which ones. The substrate can still respect the general
    connectivity flags (like allow_hidden_hidden_links) if you want. <br>
    - The distance CPPN input for HyperNEAT now works for substrates of
    any dimensionality. <br>
    - New activation functions: Relu and Softplus rectifiers. <br>
    <br>
    If you have trouble getting Boost to work with Python 3, compile it
    like this: <br>
    <br>
    ./bootstrap.sh --with-python=python3.4<br>
    ./b2 -j8<br>
    sudo ./b2 install<br>
    <br>
    OpenCV 3.0 now has Python 3 support so getting it to work shouldn't
    be a problem, though the installation may fail to copy the .so file
    in place. If that happens, locate the file manually in
    [your_build_dir]/lib/python3 and copy it in
    /usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages . <br>
    <br>
    The documentation is not updated yet, but I'll do it in the next few
    weeks when I have time. The example files should be
    self-explanatory. Of course, always feel free to ask me anything. <br>
    <br>
    Have fun! <br>
    <br>
    Peter<br>
